elements.label: paragraph
elements.text: Table 3-1 summarizes these special registers and their values.

elements.label: caption
elements.text: Table 3-1  Special registers and their corresponding values

rows: The effective user of the thread excluding adopted authority.
The effective user of the thread including adopted authority. When no adopted authority is present, this has the same value as USER.
The authorization ID that initiated the connection.

elements.label: paragraph
elements.text: Figure 3-5 shows the difference in the special register values when an adopted authority is used:

elements.label: list_item
elements.text: A user connects to the server using the user profile ALICE.

elements.label: list_item
elements.text: USER and CURRENT USER initially have the same value of ALICE.

elements.label: list_item
elements.text: ALICE calls an SQL procedure that is named proc1, which is owned by user profile JOE and was created to adopt JOE's authority when it is called.

elements.label: list_item
elements.text: While the procedure is running, the special register USER still contains the value of ALICE because it excludes any adopted authority. The special register CURRENT USER contains the value of JOE because it includes any adopted authority.

elements.label: list_item
elements.text: When proc1 ends, the session reverts to its original state with both USER and CURRENT USER having the value of ALICE.

elements.label: picture
elements.text: Diagram showing the process of special register values with adopted authority.

elements.label: caption
elements.text: Figure 3-5  Special registers and adopted authority

elements.label: paragraph
elements.text: Built-in global variables are provided with the database manager and are used in SQL statements to retrieve scalar values that are associated with the variables.

elements.label: paragraph
elements.text: IBM DB2 for i supports nine different built-in global variables that are read only and maintained by the system. These global variables can be used to identify attributes of the database connection and used as part of the RCAC logic.

elements.label: page_footer
elements.text: Chapter 3. Row and Column Access Control  19
